text: Content Standard 1.0: Students recognize the components of theatrical production including script writing, directing, and production.

children.text: Scriptwriting
Create a simple script based on personal experience, imagination, or the retelling of a story.
Create a script with two or more characters; a beginning, middle and end; setting; and character descriptions.
Write a script with appropriate format (i.e. acts, scenes), simple stage directions, cast of characters, and technical needs.
Write a script in proper format for stage, television, film, or electronic media using historical or cultural research as a basis for the script.
Directing
Work together in a group to plan, rehearse, and present a dramatized idea or story.
Direct actors or be directed by others using stage direction vocabulary.
Create a theatrical performance by conducting auditions, casting characters, directing scenes, and conducting production meetings.
Understanding Roles of Stage Personnel
Identify and describe the roles and responsibilities of stage production personnel.
Explain and demonstrate knowledge of varied responsibilities of technical personnel involved in television, theater, film or electronic media production.
Determining an Interpretation
Analyze and convey the playwright's intention.
Develop an aesthetically unified production for theater, film, television, or electronic media.
Publicity
Design and produce publicity for a production (e.g posters, flyers).
Create a variety of materials for a media campaign for theater, film, television, or electronic media.
Set Design
Create simple sets and sound effects for a dramatized idea or story (e.g. tables become caves).
Draw and/or build model sets for a production (e.g. cardboard or diorama).
Work collaboratively and safely to design and construct a box set for a production.
Work collaboratively and safely to design and/or construct a variety of scenic devices (e.g. scenic drops).
Props, Costumes, and Make-up
Assemble and use simple props, costumes, masks, or make-up for a dramatized idea or story.
Assemble props and costumes for use in a dramatized event set in a specific time period and locale (e.g. Pilgrims or Romans) .
Design and create props, costumes, and makeup for characters with attention to age, culture, and overall interpretation of a script.
Justify choices of costumes, make-up and props as they relate to the interpretation of a production.
Understanding Lighting and Sound
Identify appropriate sound and lighting effects for any dramatized event (e.g. interior, exterior).
Describe and demonstrate different lighting and sound techniques and equipment for film, stage, television, or electronic media.
Designing Lights and Sound
Create appropriate sound effects and suggest lighting for a dramatized event.
Design and/or use a light and/or sound plot for film, stage, television, or electronic media.

text: Content Standard 2.0: Students understand and demonstrate the role of the actor in the theater.

children.text: Character Analysis
Identify traits of a person, animal, or object (e.g. What does a dog do when it's happy? Wag its tail).
Identify and list a given character's traits by looking at the character's actions and dialogue.
Analyze a character to determine actions, intentions, and biography.
Analyze and describe the physical, emotional, and social dimensions of characters found in a variety of text.
Acting Skills
Imitate the traits of a given person, animal, or object.
Demonstrate examples of character traits through movement, pantomime, improvisation, and/or voice. (e.g. How does a person move and speak at age 60? At age 6?).
Demonstrate acting skills utilizing appropriate focus/concentration, breathing and vocal techniques, memory and sensory recall, and physical movement.
Identify, examine, and demonstrate various classical and contemporary acting techniques and methods.
Characterization
Use voice and body to show different emotions while portraying a character in a dramatized idea or story.
Portray a character's traits through movement, voice and/or dialogue in a dramatized idea or story.
Create and sustain a believable character for stage.
Create and sustain a character within an ensemble for stage, film, television, or electronic media.

text: Content Standard 3.0 Students apply and demonstrate critical and creative thinking skills in theater, film television, or electronic media.

children.text: Production / Performance Analysis
Discuss performances of students and visiting artists.
Evaluate the established elements of theater found in a dramatized performance.
Critique the effectiveness of the visual, aural, and kinesthetic elements of a performance.
Aesthetic Criteria
Express personal reactions to a dramatized performance.
Describe emotional response to a performance and explain genre preference (e.g. romance, comedy, suspense, and action).
Analyze the emotional impact of the visual, aural, and kinesthetic elements of a performance.
Justify personal aesthetic criteria for critiquing a dramatized performance.
Genre Identification
Identify the differences between fantasy and reality.
Differentiate between comedy and tragedy.
Identify examples of, high and low comedy and tragedy.
Compare and contrast classical and contemporary dramas and comedies in various media.

text: Content Standard 4.0 Students recognize and explain how theatrical experiences contribute to a better understanding of history, culture, and human relationships.

children.text: History and Culture
Explain how movies or television reveal information about other historical periods and cultures.
Explain how theater reveals information about other historical periods and cultures.
Compare and contrast the ways in which universal themes and archetypes in dramatized events are expressed in another culture and another historical period.
Human Relationships
Identify similarities and differences between dramatic characters and real people.
Identify the conflict between characters in a dramatized event.
Identify the sources of conflict between characters in a dramatized event.
Analyze methods of conflict resolution among characters.

text: Content Standard 5.0 Students make connections with theater, the other arts, and academic disciplines.

children.text: Connection to Other Arts
Identify and explain how the choices of visual arts, dance, and music enhance the interpretation of a dramatic event.
Analyze the ways in which common themes or stories are interpreted in works from the four arts areas.
Connection to History
Explain the roots of theater in Western civilization.
Analyze the development of dramatic forms, production practices, and theatrical traditions across cultures and historical periods.
Connection to Other Academic Disciplines
Explain how advancements in the sciences have enhanced dramatized events (e.g. special effects, sound that surrounds the audience).
Evaluate different ways technology is used to enhance theater, film, and television.
